Fig. 1 Catalytic performance of (a) Ru/MnO2 relative to Ru/MnCo2O4 and Ru/MnFe2O4 upon oxidation of conc. (2 wt% aqueous) HMF (3 h) (b) kinetics of conc.(2 wt% aqueous) HMF oxidation over Ru/MnO2 (c) kinetics of dilute (0.63wt% aqueous) HMF oxidation over Ru/MnO2 and (d) recyclability of Ru/MnO2 with dilute (0.63 wt%) and conc. (2 wt%) aqueous HMF feed (24 h). Conditions: HMF:Ru = 32 (Ru loading was 5 wt%) and HMF/Mn=1.47, 100 °C, 30 bar O2, 1000 rpm. HMF (2 wt% aqueous). Conditions: HMF:Ru = 32, 100 °C, 30 bar O2, 1000 rpm, 24 h (for graph 2a). Figure 2 Fig. 3 (a) 1H NMR and (b) powder XRD patterns of FDCA obtained from HMF oxidation over Ru/MnO2. Figure 3 Fig. 4 (a) Single Crystal structure of Mn-FDCA asymmetric unit. (b) Mn of Mn-FDCA shows 6 coordination. (c) Crystal packing diagram along a-axis, (d) b-axis and (e) c-axis. The packing extended via distorted trigonal bipyramidal (polyhyra). Figure 4 Fig. 5 (a) FE-SEM images (b) EDX micro elemental mapping (C, O and Mn) images of Mn-FDCA formed during base free HMF oxidation in the presnce of Ru/MnO2 catalyst. Figure 6 Fig. 7 Comparison of (a) powder XRD patterns and (b) Mn3s regions of pristine Ru/MnO2 and spent catalyst recovered from HMF oxidation under different conditions. Marg Bhavnagar Gujarat 364002 India 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a high value bio-based chemical useful for the production of next generation renewable polymers, epoxy-resins and surfactants. Herein, we show that the performance and stability of MnO2 based oxidation catalysts used in FDCA production are considerably influence by process conditions (especially initial HMF conc. and presence of base additives). Although, base free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA is known to be highly effective over Ru modified MnO2 catalysts, our experiments showed considerable leaching of MnO2 phase under reaction conditions with the formation of insoluble Mn-FDCA complexes. The formation of Mn-FDCA complex and Mn leaching was also supported by control experiments between FDCA and various Mn oxides under hydrothermal conditions and its structure confirmed by single crystal XRD. Formation of Mn-FDCA and Mn leaching was also identified as the underlying reason for carbon balance deficit, catalyst mass loss and deactivation observed upon reuse. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords HMF oxidation MnO2 based oxidation catalysts catalyst stability acid promoted Mn-leaching Mn-FDCA complex Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the current scenario, non-regenerative coal and petroleum remains the primary source of energy, chemicals, and materials used in our everyday life. In terms of alternatives feedstocks, biomass remains the only source of sustainable carbon suitable for the production of various petroleum equivalent products such as chemicals, carbonaceous liquid fuels and materials (e.g. polymers) [1–4]. As a result, in recent years the concept of biorefining and has gained considerable momentum, in brief biorefinery is industrial complex in which renewable biomass feedstocks are processed in a similar to petroleum refinery to produce a wide spectrum useful products that include fuels, materials, chemicals and energy [1–5]. Due to the abundance and widespread availability, lignocellulosic biomass composed mainly of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin has received the most attention. In fact, many existing industries utilizing woody biomass (e.g. pulp and paper mills, sugar mills) as a feedstock are perhaps the closest example of a modern-day biorefinery, and such complexes maybe further modified to coproduce value added products like ethanol, vanillin [5]. For example, large number of efficient enzymatic as well as catalytic strategies has been developed for the transformation cellulose and hemicellulose, components in lignocellulose to the corresponding C5-C6 monosaccharides. Methods have also been developed for the enzymatic as well as chemo catalytic conversion of these monosaccharides to versatile chemicals, such as lactic acid, ethanol, butanol, diols, furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and to name a few. Among these, HMF derived from the dehydration of C6 monosaccharides is a key platform compound for producing a variety of value-added chemical products such as levulinic acid (LA), γ-valerolactone (GVL), 2,5-diformyl furan (DFF), 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) and furanic diols (2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran) [6–9]. Among these, the oxidized derivative 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is high value chemical of commercial relevance, as it has been identified as a precursor for the production of next generation renewable polymer polyethylenefuranoate (PEF a green substitute to PET), green-epoxy-resins and green-surfactants (Scheme 1 ). DFF is another useful oxidation product which can also be used for the synthesis of various furanic polymers, furan-urea resins as well as numerous other pharmaceutically important chemicals [8,9]. Apart from the preparation of polymers and surfactants, FDCA can potentially be also used as a platform for the synthesis of various useful chemicals such as adipic acid, succinic acid, 2,5-bis(aminomethylfuran) etc.[10]. Although, FDCA has been synthesized from HMF using commercially available homogeneous oxidants like HNO3, N2O4, KMnO4 Co-Mn acetates with bromides (Mid-Century oxidation) [11–13]. Such homogenous approach has many inherent drawbacks such as, corrosion, requirement of specialized equipment and most importantly the generation of huge amount of wastes, which creates various environmental as well industrial scale up issues [14]. Thus, in recent years, efforts have been made towards utilizing environmentally benign air or molecular oxygen as a green oxidant for FDCA production preferably in the presence of solid catalysts. Till date, numerous studies have been undertaken which depicts efficient oxidation of HMF to FDCA, especially various noble (Pt, Au, Pd and Ru) as well as non-noble (Mn, Fe) metal or their mixture based homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts using various oxidants including air as well molecular oxygen [15–32]. Among the various metals catalysts reported, Ru and Mn have particularly gained considerable attention due to their low-cost (relative to noble metals like Pt, Au and Pd) and excellent catalytic activity in oxidation reactions which has been attributed to the existence of variable oxidation states (-2 to +8 for Ru and +2 to +7 for Mn) that facilitates ease of oxygen absorption, oxidation-reduction, and increases oxygen storage capacity [28]. In particular, various Ru modified MnO2 materials (mono as well as bimetallic) have demonstrated exceptionally high activity for aerobic oxidation of aqueous HMF under industrially relevant base free conditions [30,32]. Although, various Ru free systems incorporating Mn oxides have also demonstrated good-excellent performance upon the same reaction with FDCA yields reaching close to ∼85-91%, such catalysts require the use of strong liquid oxidants such as tert-butyl hydroperoxide, or a very high catalyst dosage (catalyst:HMF (w/w) = 2 or higher, corresponding to non-catalytic loadings) and base (e.g. NaOH, KOH or NaHCO3) as promoters [24–28]. For example, Hara et al. reported FDCA yields up to 91% in the presence of commercial activated MnO2 as a catalyst and NaHOC3 as a promoter upon aerobic oxidation of HMF. The authors also co-related the activity of MnO2 catalysts with its crystal structure whereupon materials with lower vacancy formation energies were shown to more active [25]. In another work by Wang et al., MnOx–CeO2 mixed oxide was also shown to afforded upto 91% FDCA yield upon aerobic HMF oxidation in the presence of tert-butyl hydroperoxide as oxidant [24]. In contrast, the Ru modified counterparts are reported to afforded significantly improved performance with much lower catalyst dosage (i.e. catalytic amounts) even under base free conditions [27,29-32]. For example, Kim et al. showed that over Ru decorated Mn-Co and Mn spinel oxides FDCA yields reached 90-99% in 10 h at 120 °C in the presence of 30 bar O2 during oxidation of aqueous HMF under base free conditions [32]. In another work, Saravanamurugan and co-workers reported the application of a basic Ru/MnO2 catalyst with a dominant ϵ-MnO2 phase for the base free oxidation of aqueous HMF, affording FDCA yields upto 87% at 140 °C [30]. However, a plausible drawback of the base free approach lies in the requirement of complicated work up such as base treatment followed by acidification, required to separate catalyst particles from FDCA, this is particularly important when working with HMF streams with higher concentrations (1 wt% or higher), which may cause rapid precipitation of produced FDCA in the reaction mixture. Moreover, in spite of the good-initial activities, in most of the studies considerable change in catalyst performance have been observed upon reuse, and the spent catalyst often required regenerative treatments such as calcination to maintain its original activity [30–32]. Further, a closer look at the literature data also shows that in the past reusability of RuMn-oxide catalysts have been typically studied at low conversion or intermediate oxidation level, where the possibility of acidic product (e.g. FDCA, FFCA produced upon deep/tandem oxidation) induced metal (Ru, Mn) leaching could be ruled out [30–33]. Thus, it is safe to conclude that there is a lack of experimental data substantiating stability of RuMn-oxides during deep HMF oxidation under base free conditions, and further investigations are still need to carefully re-examine the stability of such supported Mn catalysts, considering the fate of all metallic species involved in supported Mn catalysts under reaction conditions (Ru, Mn and/or other metals). This is particularly relevant when working under base free conditions and utilizing conc. HMF as substrate and, aiming at deep oxidation which produce highly acidic dicarboxylic acid FDCA as the main product. Under such conditions the possibility Mn leaching cannot be completely ruled out, considering the well documented tendency of MnO2 particles to readily leach/solubilize under acidic conditions especially in the presence of reducing species such as carbohydrates, citric acid etc. Similarly, Mn2+ leaching from various MnO2 containing ores as well as commercial MnO2 has been shown to occur with organic dicarboxylic acids such as oxalic acid, ascorbic acid as well as FDCA [25,34]. Further, the possibility of complexation between Mn (or leached Mn species) and FDCA cannot also be ruled out considering its similarity with dicarboxylic acids like terephthalic acid and the well documented synthesis of various Mn–dicarboxylic acid metal organic frameworks (Mn-BDC), readily obtained by the direct reaction between Mn salts with dicarboxylic acid (such as terephthalic acid) under hydrothermal conditions [35]. A close examination of the prior art also shows that, very few reports are available which depict deep oxidation of concentrated HMF feeds, typically when using a high HMF dosage often low FDCA yields are obtained due to the formation partially oxidized products as well as undesirable HMF degradation products [36–37]. Recently, Dumesic and co-workers demonstrated deep oxidation of conc. HMF (upto 7 wt. %, derived from fructose) affording FDCA in yields upto 99% utilizing water-GVL mixture as solvent with good catalyst recyclability, however the process employed expensive Pt/C catalysts with very high loadings (HMF/Pt =10) [38]. Thus, considering the points highlighted above and the importance of utilization of conc. HMF streams for efficient, large scale FDCA production and the documented performance (high productivity) of relatively inexpensive and easy to synthesize Ru supported and/or promoted MnO2 (or RuMn oxide) catalysts upon aerobic deep oxidation of (dilute) aqueous HMF under base free conditions; the present study has been taken up to evaluate the performance and particularly re-evaluate the stability of such catalysts during deep oxidation of conc. HMF streams (upto 10 wt%) under base free conditions [27,29-32,39]. In the current work, experiments were also conducted/designed to carefully investigate the fate of Mn as well as other metallic species present in the supported catalyst during HMF aerobic oxidation under reaction conditions. Strategies were also developed to check metal leaching and inhibit catalyst activity loss. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalytic materials All reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received (for details refer to supporting information). Analytical grade O2 was procured locally and used as received. Double deionised water was used in catalyst preparation as well as the reaction media in catalytic reactions. Unless specified the bimetallic Ru/MnO2 oxidation catalysts were obtained by the wetness impregnation method using ruthenium (III) trichloride hydrate (Sigma) as the Ru precursor, using MnO2 supports synthesized in house as well as from commercial sources. In a typical synthesis, 5 g support (MnO2) was dispersed in 100 ml deionised water, followed by slow addition of an aqueous ruthenium (III) trichloride solution (50 g/L) to achieve desired Ru loading (5 wt%). Next the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min followed by heating at 80 °C for 3 h under constant stirring. Finally, the obtained black particles (i.e. Ru/MnO2) were filtered, washed with adequate deionized water (until free from Cl−) and dried in an oven at 110 °C for 8 h. To determine Ru uptake on the supports, the ruthenium (III) trichloride solution solutions (before and after impregnation) were analysed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), which revealed complete Ru uptake by all the MnO2 based supports, indicating actual loadings to be identical to the designed loadings. The specific details of the different MnO2 supports used in the study along with their synthetic procedures are provided in supporting information. For comparison, the previously reported Ru/MnCo2O4 catalyst as well as MnCo2O4 were prepared according to the procedures described by Kim et al. [32] 2.2 Catalytic material characterization The obtained catalytic materials and the supports were characterized by standard techniques to evaluate their structure, composition, morphology and textural properties. The details of the characterization techniques are provided in supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic reaction procedures HMF oxidation was conducted under base fee as well as in the presence of base additives, using different concentrations of HMF feed (0.63-10 wt%). In all experiments HMF:catalyst (w/w) ratio was maintained at 2. In a typical reaction the reactor was charged with the desired amount of HMF (1 mmol, at the desired dilution), catalyst and flushed up to five times with O2. Next the reactor was pressurized to the desired reaction pressure (10-30 bar), and the contents heated to the desired reaction temperature (100 °C) under magnetic stirring. In select reactions NaHCO3 (2 mmol) was also added an additive. It should be noted that, oxidation experiments with diluted HMF (0.63 wt%) were conducted in a 100 ml reactor whereas a smaller 13 ml reactor was used for performing experiments with concentrated HMF (2 wt%, 5 wt% and 10 wt%) for practical difficulties in stirring. Following reaction, the reactor was cooled, depressurized and the reaction mixture diluted with methanol (to ensure complete solubilization of all oxidation products) and subjected to centrifugation to separate the solid catalyst particles from reaction mixture. For quantitative analysis of reaction products and conversion the reaction mixture was passed through 0.22 µm syringe filters and analysed by HPLC in a Thermo scientific (Ultimate 3000) HPLC system equipped with diode array detector (DAD) (210 nm). The reactant and the formed oxidation products were separated using an Aminex-87H column using 5 mM H2SO4 as the mobile phase (0.6 ml/min), during analysis the column temperature was kept at 50 °C and injection volume of each sample set as 5 µL. The concentrations of the formed furan compounds were calculated using standard calibration curve method obtained by injecting known concentration of authentic samples from commercial sources. (1) % conversion = C 0 ( HMF ) − C t ( HMF ) C 0 ( HMF ) × 100 (2) % yield = C p C 0 ( HMF ) × 100 (3) % selectivity = C p C 0 ( HMF ) − C t ( HMF ) × 100 (3.a) % carbon balance = C t ( HMF ) + C total C 0 ( HMF ) × 100 Where, C 0 ( HMF ) and C t ( HMF ) represent the initial and final concentration of HMF, C p denotes the concentration of product (DFF, FFCA, HMFCA and FDCA) formed in mol/L and C total = C t ( FDCA ) + C t ( FFCA ) + C t ( DFF ) + C t ( HMFCA ) , the total concentration of all organic components detected in mol/L. 2.4 Analysis of reaction mixture and products Collected reaction mixtures were also analysed by 1H-NMR using DMSO as a solvent. Liquid aliquots collected from reactions were also digested in HNO3 and analysed by ICP-MS to check for leaching of active metals (Ru, Mn, Fe and/or Co) present in the catalyst. Product isolated from reaction mixtures were characterized by XRD as well as single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Results of initial catalyst screening upon HMF oxidation under base free conditions For initial benchmarking of the synthesized RuMn oxide catalysts, deep oxidation of aqueous HMF was conducted under base free conditions keeping reaction conditions comparable to those typically reported in literature (i.e. diluted 6.3 g/L or 0.63 wt% aq. HMF as substrate, 100 °C, and HMF:Ru = 32, 12 h). The results summarized in Table 1 , clearly demonstrate the excellent performance of RuMn catalysts obtained by redox reactions affording 100% HMF conversion with excellent FDCA yields (87-91%) which was comparable to that of the benchmark RuMn catalysts reported in literature [30–32]. In contrast, under identical conditions control experiments with the pristine supports afforded no HMF conversion. However, it should be noted that synthesized MnO2 materials could afford a high FDCA yield in 24 h, especially when using a higher catalyst loading and in the presence of NaHCO3 (as additive), under experimental conditions similar to those of of Hara and co-workers [25]. This observation was in good agreement with the high catalytic activity of MnO2 materials synthesized by redox reactions which was en par with active MnO2 catalysts reported in prior art [25]. Overall, our findings are comparable with the trends reported in prior art, and in strong agreement with the synergistic effect of Ru-Mn oxides promoting the catalytic performance of these materials upon oxidative transformation aqueous HMF (Table 1) [30–32]. The excellent catalytic performance of synthesized catalytic materials could be attributed to dominance of oxygen vacancy rich γ MnO2 phase (Figure S4-S5, supporting information) [25,30]. The characterization results of redox reaction derived γ phase rich MnO2, commercial MnO2 and RuMn oxide catalysts are included in supporting information (XRD, XPS, TGA, SEM, TEM, TPD etc, Figure S1-S6 and Table S1). A detailed discussion on the structure and properties of as synthesized catalysts are not included in the main text as such discussions are beyond the scope of the current study (which deals primely with stability and deactivation aspects). However, a comparative discussion on the structure and physico-chemical of pristine and spent catalysts are included in Section 3.5 (see below), as such discussion was crucial for explaining the fate of these catalyst during HMF oxidation and the ensuing deactivation phenomena. 3.2 Base free oxidation of concentrated HMF streams Motivated by the promising results obtained upon base free oxidation of diluted HMF, we further evaluated the performance of the active RuMn oxide catalysts using a more concentrated aqueous HMF stream (20 g/L or 2 wt%) as the feed. The data presented in Fig. 1 (a), highlights, the excellent performance of synthesized Ru/MnO2 which was found to be comparable to the benchmark Ru/MnCo2O4; further confirming the high efficacy of γ MnO2 rich RuMn oxides obtained by redox reactions as oxidation catalysts [25,30,32]. This observation was further supported by the fact that a α phase rich Ru/MnO2 material derived from commercial MnO2, afforded ca. 28% lower FDCA yield (43% vs. 60%) during base free oxidation of 2 wt% HMF under identical conditions. Fig. 1(b-c) shows conversion, carbon balance and the yield of different oxidation products during base free oxidation of aqueous HMF at two different concentrations over the active Ru/MnO2 catalyst. From the data presented in Fig. 1(b-c), it is clear that when using a diluted feed superior catalytic performance with higher HMF conversion rate as well as FDCA formation rates could be observed. Nevertheless, at 12-24 h when deep oxidation was prevalent, for both cases FDCA remained as the only product. Interestingly, in case of 2 wt% HMF feed FDCA yield could reach a maximum of 60%, while for 0.63 wt% feed it reached ca. 89%. Another, important observation from the data in Fig. 1(b-c) was the carbon balance deficit observed (89-59%) when FDCA remained as the sole/main product, which was found to be more significant for the concentrated HMF feed (40% vs. 89%). Although, such carbon balance deficit could be attributed to the precipitation of FDCA at high concentrations, in this study we also explored the possibility of Mn-FDCA complexation and Mn leaching, in light of the spectral broadening observed upon 1H NMR analysis of reaction products which characterised the presence of paramagnetic species or impurities in the reaction mixture (see below). To further understand in the influence of initial HMF concentration on carbon balance deficit and FDCA yield, experiments were also conducted using 5 wt% and 10% HMF as substrate (Fig. 2 (a)), although all reactions produced FDCA as the only detectable product in 24 h we observed considerable drop in both carbon balance and FDCA yield with increased feed concentration reaching minimum at 10% HMF in agreement with the decreased solubility of FDCA. Moreover, as expected the pH of reaction mixture decreased with increased initial feed concentration reaching a minimum of 2 for 10% HMF, in good agreement with increased concentration of acidic products in reaction mixture. It is also worth highlighting, here that upon work up reaction mixture obtained from concentrated HMF feed (2 wt%), with additional base treatment, followed by precipitation and resolubilization in methanol; afforded substantially improved carbon balance (>90%) with 83% isolated FDCA yield, comparable to the isolated yields obtained with the diluted HMF feed, in agreement with the precipitation of FDCA under process conditions. These findings support the plausible formation of insoluble/precipitated FDCA and/or FDCA-catalyst intermediates on catalyst surface which are most likely released upon work up with base addition. The formation of these stable insoluble adducts on the catalyst surface was also supported by experiential data such as NMR, XRD and single crystal XRD (see below). 3.3 Stability of RuMn catalysts during HMF oxidation Further, to examine the stability of RuMn oxide catalysts under base free conditions in the presence of acidic products at different concentrations, reusability studies were conducted with both dilute and concentrated aq. HMF as the feed. To conduct reusability studies after the completion of reaction, to the diluted reaction mixture (with methanol) stoichiometric amount of base (2 eq. NaOH with respect to HMF) was added to ensure complete solubilization of FDCA (as Na-FDCA salt) and the black solid catalyst particles separated from the products by filtration. The recovered catalysts particles were washed with adequate deionized water, methanol and dried in an oven at 100°C for overnight and used for the consecutive recycling experiments. It should be noted that while in previous studies utilizing RuMn-oxide catalysts upon base free oxidation of HMF, catalyst recyclability was investigated at internment oxidation level (or under kinetic regime) where the concentration of acidic products such as FFCA and FDCA (formed upon deep oxidation of HMF) remained (relatively) low [30–32]. In contrast herein, we opted to investigate catalyst recyclability at 24 h when concentration of deep oxidation acidic products was maximum (Fig. 1(a-c)). This was done considering the possibility of acidic product induced Mn leaching (confirmed by ICP, see below) under base free conditions, in view of the substantial carbon balance deficit observed (especially with concentrated HMF feeds) and also in order to maximize the contact between catalyst particles and acidic product FDCA to study possible complexation between Mn and FDCA. As initial concentration of HMF directly influences FDCA concentration, yield and acidity of resulting product mixture in the reactor (Fig. 2(a)), we also evaluated the influence of initial HMF concentration on catalyst recyclability. Moreover, under industrial setting in order to maximize productivity and reduce the number of downstream processing steps it is likely that the catalyst will be recycled only after affording maximum yield of desired product i.e. FDCA (here), thus it is imperative that catalyst reusability/stability is also investigated under similar settings to get a more realistic insights into the stability of catalyst under operational/ process conditions. As expected, the reusability data shown in Fig. 1(d), indicated gradual loss of catalyst activity with ca. 20% reduction in FDCA yield at the third cycle even when using diluted HMF as feed, while for concentrated HMF substrate, FDCA yield reduced by ca. 33% at the first cycle clearly showing the significant negative impact of acidic products formed on catalyst reuse performance, which didn't improve visibly even after regenerative treatments such as calcination [30,44]. The trends observed herein were significantly different from those reported in literature whereupon activity loss was shown to be only marginal or insignificant when using diluted feeds at intermittent oxidation (where non acidic products such as DFF remained as the major product), an observation consistent with the absence of acidic product induced deactivation due to Mn leaching (see below) as well as other traditional deactivation pathways (such as sintering, fouling, Ru leaching) under kinetic regime or at intermittent oxidation level [30,32,39,40,41]. However, our findings are clearly indicative of the obvious effects of acidity, i.e. acidic product (FDCA) as well as initial substrate (HMF) concentration (which in turn effects acidity of reaction mixture) on the reusability and stability of Ru supported Mn-oxide i.e. RuMn-oxide catalysts (Fig. 1(a-d) and Fig. 2(a)). Although, MnO2 has been regarded to be reasonably stable in hot water (used as a reaction media in the study), its stability has been shown to be drastically altered by the presence both reducing, oxidising species and especially in acids; for example the reductive as well as oxidative leaching of MnO2 particles in the presence of various oxidising and reducing agents as well as corrosion of MnO2 based electrodes in oxygen reduction (ORR) and oxygen evolution (OER) reactions are well documented and the trends observed herein are also no exception depicting acid induced Mn leaching under oxidising conditions (see below) [34,41,42,43]. In fact, a study by Hara et al. reported substantial leaching of Mn (upto 13%) from unsupported MnO2 catalysts during HMF oxidation under base free conditions (however it is to be noted an extremely high non-catalytic dosage of MnO2 i.e. 400 wt% with respect to. HMF was required that to afford good catalytic performance), whereas promotion of MnO2 with small amount of Ru (1-5 wt%), results in substantial improvement of catalyst activity (Table 1) [44]. Therefore, further investigations are needed to understand the fate of MnO2 species present in different supported MnO2 catalysts (especially Ru supported MnO2 catalysts) during base fee oxidative transformations of molecules such as HMF in aqueous environments, where acidic products like FDCA formed could promote Mn leaching [44]. In view of this, we carefully analysed the reaction mixtures obtained with the different RuMn catalysts (Ru/MnO2, Ru/MnCo2O4 and Ru/MnO2-Fe2O3) via. ICP-MS which revealed considerable leaching of Mn species from all the catalyst into the reaction mixture (Table 2 , Fig. 2(a) and Table S2, Supporting information). In fact, under base free conditions we observed substantial leaching of Mn species ranging from 139 to 988 ppm, which accounts to ca. 4.2 to 10% leaching of all Mn from the RuMn catalysts, which was comparable to the 13% Mn leaching reported by Hara et al. for unmodified MnO2 catalysts, and overall in strong agreement with the previously reported data depicting poor stability of MnO2 particles in presence of acids under reducing/oxidising conditions [34,40,41,42,44]. In contrast for all catalysts leaching of Ru species were insignificant (<2 ppm) and less than 0.5% of total Ru present in catalyst (Table 2), which was consistent with the literature reports depicting the robustness of Ru/RuOX phase in RuMn oxide-based catalysts [30,32,39,40]. Interestingly, among the catalysts based on bimetallic Mn supports viz. MnCo2O4 and MnFe2O4, Co leaching was also found to be substantial (641 ppm) while no Fe leaching was observed for the MnFe2O4 based catalytic material. Although, presence of Fe in MnO2 structure was shown to improve the stability of MnO2 phase and substantially reduce Mn leaching, the catalytic performance of MnFe based catalyst was found to significantly inferior to that of the benchmark Ru/MnCo2O4 and Ru/MnO2 materials (Fig. 1(a)), which may limit is applicability as an oxidation catalyst, especially with concentrated HMF feeds. 3.4 Mechanism of Mn leaching and catalyst deactivation To gain further insights into the mechanism of Mn leaching during reaction, we plotted metal leaching as a function of reaction time, which revealed a positive correlation between leached Mn species and reaction time (Fig. 2(b)). Further, comparison of the trend in Fig. 2(a,b) with the kinetics or product distribution plots in Fig. 1(b), was clearly indicative of the promotional effect of increased concentration of acidic products viz. FFCA and FDCA (pKa = 2.76) in increasing Mn leaching. Moreover, when FDCA remained as the only or major oxidation product carbon balance dropped sharply which could be attributed to the precipitation of FDCA (or Mn-FDCA complex) at high concentrations, Fig. 2(a,b) [38]. Moreover, comparison of the leaching data at full conversion for Ru/MnO2 with the two different HMF feeds show comparatively higher Mn leaching in case of concentrated feed (1340 ppm or 14% for 2 wt% HMF vs. 325 ppm or 10% for 0.63 wt% HMF), supportive of the role of increased concentration of FDCA in increasing acidity of reaction mixture and thereby enhancing Mn leaching (Fig. 2(a)). The trends in Fig. 2, were also consistent with the superior recyclability observed for RuMn catalyst reported in literature where upon at intermittent oxidation level (i.e. when DFF remains the major product) and use of diluted feeds results in significantly less acidic environment which leads to considerably supressed Mn leaching [30,32,39,43,44,46]. Even so, form the leaching data in Table 2 and recyclability data in Fig. 1(d), it is evident that under base free conditions acidic product induced Mn leaching does occur irrespective of initial HMF concentration or catalyst composition which negatively impact catalyst reuse performance and lifetime. Thus, our results clearly highlight the importance of studying deactivation behavior of catalysts in both kinetic regime as well as equilibrium regime. In fact, there are many instances when catalyst deactivation maybe more pronounced under equilibrium regime, for example due to deposition of high boiling or strong adsorption of products or due to product induced leaching or coking/sintering as observed herein upon base free oxidation of HMF with Mn based catalysts [41,45–47]. Another, important observation in our study was the formation of needle like crystals upon concentration of the completely oxidised products (FDCA) without any work up, which when analysed by 1H NMR, produced broad signals (Fig. 3 (a)). In contrast, the FDCA samples obtained by the standard work up procedures (i.e. solubilization with base followed by precipitation with acid), exhibited the characteristic sharp signals of FDCA around 7.2 ppm (Fig. 3(a)), similar to those reported by Kim et al. [32]. Moreover, the products obtained by work up also did not form needle like crystals. This difference was indicative of the plausible formation of complex/adducts between FDCA and leached Mn species (Mn-FDCA) under hydrothermal conditions and consistent with the presence of paramagnetic (Mn) impurities in the collected products (FDCA). The leaching behavior and the Mn complexation/adduct formation with FDCA was also further supported by the considerable mass loss (ca. 15-30%) incurred during catalyst recycling, and also in good agreement the well documented synthesis of similar Mn–BDC type metal organic frameworks via. reaction between Mn precursors and terephthalic acid under comparable hydrothermal conditions [35]. Thus, to further validate the mechanism of MnO2 leaching from RuMn catalysts during oxidative conversion of HMF, a series of control experiments were also conducted by reacting FDCA with different Mn sources (including the catalysts and supports) under hydrothermal conditions (keeping conditions similar to reaction, HMF/Mn = 1.47) and the results summarized in Table 3 . The ICP-MS data presented in Table 3, clearly indicate the presence of considerable amount of soluble Mn species (ca. 4.5-22% Mn leached) irrespective of Mn source, which confirmed the FDCA induced solubilization various Mn-oxides under hot hydrothermal conditions similar to those observed during HMF oxidative transformation. Among, the investigated materials Ru/MnFe2O4 mixed presented lowest Mn leaching, however its catalytic efficacy was drastically inferior to the two other catalyst (Ru/MnCo2O4 and Ru/MnO2) (Fig. 1(c)) and, also Mn dissolution although reduced was found be still substantial (4.5 %) in view of catalytic application. Further, similar to the reaction products obtained during oxidative HMF conversion to FDCA formation of needle like crystals were also observed upon concentration of liquid products from the control reaction between FDCA and the various Mn sources (Table 3), which when subjected to 1H NMR analysis also gave rise to the characteristic spectral broadening feature, indicative of the presence of paramagnetic Mn impurities in the crystalline products (Supporting information, Figure S6). To confirm the nature of these products/adducts formed powder XRD patterns of these samples were recorded, which revealed a distinctive pattern characteristic of an ordered crystalline material which was different from FDCA, similar patterns were also obtained for the products obtained from oxidative HMF conversion under base free conditions (Fig. 3(b), Fig. 4 and Figure S7, supporting information) [46]. In order to solve the structure of these materials, samples were also analysed by single crystal XRD, which confirmed the formation of Mn-FDCA complex's (CCDD No. 2286407) in both cases (HMF oxidation as well as control FDCA-Ru/MnO2 catalyst reactions) similar to FDCA based metal organic frameworks (MOFs) Hf-FDCA and Zr-FDCA, recently reported by Valente and co-workers [47]. The crystal structure of Mn-FDCA is shown Fig. 4, Mn-FDCA crystallized in the orthorhombic crystal system (space group Pnma) consisting of a two FDCA unit bonded to one Mn atom hydrated with three water molecules, Fig. 4(b); which was different from the well-known benzene dicarboxylic acid based (Mn-BDC) based MOFs [35]. Further, the Mn-FDCA crystals obtained from HMF oxidation was also analysed by FE-SEM and EDX, which revealed the material posed an ordered morphology with polygon like particles, subsequent EDX analysis and micro elemental mapping revealed presence of C, O and Mn with uniform distribution of Mn, most importantly the C/Mn ratio ∼12 corresponds well with the single crystal structure (Fig. 5 ). To summarize, our experimental findings, gives major insights into the hydrothermal stability of MnO2 phase in RuMn oxide catalysts, during HMF aerobic oxidation under base free conditions, and indicate to a deactivation pathway promoted by the solubilization of MnO2 species to reaction mixture in the presence of acidic FFCA, FDCA products under aqueous hydrothermal conditions, which is followed by further complexation between solubilized Mn and FDCA leading to the formation Mn-FDCA MOF like materials. In-fact, at full conversion, when FDCA remained as the sole product the reaction mixture was found to be highly acidic with pH as low as ∼3. The MnO2 dissolution was most likely further enhanced by the presence of O2 which can lead to the formation soluble MnO4 − species, and also the possibility of reductive leaching of MnO2 although less likely cannot be entirely ruled out considering the 240-740 ppm Mn leaching observed at low-conversion/intermittent oxidation (Fig. 2) (Scheme 2 ) [34,40,41,43,44,48]. Our hypothesis regarding acidic dissolution of MnO2 to be the primary cause for deactivation is also supported by the fact that in the presence of a weak bases such as NaHCO3, Mn leaching/solubilization substantially supressed (7-35 ppm vs. 988 ppm), as also reported by Hara and co-workers for unsupported/pristine MnO2 catalysts (Table 2 and Table 3) [25,44]. 3.5 Discussion and plausible approaches for deactivation mitigation Upon identification of acidic product (FDCA) promoted Mn dissolution as the primary cause for deactivation of RuMn-oxide catalysts during oxidative transformation of HMF under base free conditions. We explored three different strategies to prevent acidic dissolution of Mn phase viz. (a) base addition (to facilitate soluble FDCA salt formation) (b) methanol addition (to facilitate soluble FDCA methyl ester formation) and (c) γ-valerolactone addition (to facilitate FDCA solubilization) using the active γ Ru/MnO2 synthesized from redox reactions as a model catalyst. However, to our surprise in the presence of methanol and γ-valerolactone, catalyst performance dropped considerably along with the formation of solvent degradation products such as formic acid, as the active catalyst also promoted the oxidation of solvents, which made this approach impractical (Table 4 ). In contrast, in the presence of a weak base (NaHCO3) both catalyst activity and stability showed marked improvement, with FDCA yield and carbon balance reaching >99% in 3 h (Table 4). Similar, results were also obtained for commercial MnO2 derived Ru/MnO2, Ru/MnFe2O4 and Ru/MnCo2O4 affording 100% HMF conversion with FDCA yields of 74%, 90% and 94% respectively with negligible leaching of Mn and improved carbon balance (∼100%). The inferior performance of commercial MnO2 derived catalyst was consistent with presence of a less active α MnO2 phase (Table 2). In fact, a similar promotional effect has also been observed by Saravanamurugan and co-workers for an organic base pyridine, affording ca. 2.8-fold enhancement in FDCA yield, when compared to the base free conditions for a similar Ru/ϵ-MnO2 catalyst [30]. Most importantly, in the presence of stoichiometric amount of NaHCO3 (with respect to FDCA) Mn leaching dropped upto 190-fold, an observation consistent with the beneficial/promotional effect of weak base additives in inhibiting the dissolution of MnO2 phase in RuMn-oxide catalysts, as also observed upon unsupported MnO2 catalysts by Hara et al. [44]. Further, unlike base-free conditions showing a steady drop in catalyst activity in the presence of NaHCO3 as additive, catalyst performance remained fairly stable even at full/deep oxidation (Fig. 1(d)); which was indicative of the imperative role Mn leaching in contributing towards catalyst deactivation, Fig. 6 (a). Although, Ru leaching increased to ∼40 ppm in the presence NaHCO3 in the 1st cycle, it was not substantial in the consecutive cycles, an observation consistent with the constant FDCA yield observed upon successive reuse cycles, Fig. 5(a-b). Another, interesting observation in our investigation was the formation of solvent oxidation products (mainly HCOOH) when HMF oxidation was conducted in methanol media with NaHCO3 additive, highlighting the importance of H2O as an inert reaction media, and also the inability of Ru supported MnO2 catalyst to form oxidative esterification products like furan-2,5-dimethylcarboxylate (FDMC) typically obsrved for Au, Cu or Co based catalysts reported in literature (Table S3, supporting information) [49]. Overall, our observations are in good agreement with the recent report of Yan et al. depicting MnO2 as excellent catalysts for aerobic oxidation of aqueous alcohols to formic acid [50]. Our experimental findings are also supported by post mortem analysis of spent catalyst obtained under the two different conditions (base free vs. with NaHCO3 additive), which revealed drastic structural, compositional and textural changes occurring under base free conditions due to the acidic product (FDCA) induced leaching or etching of Mn species from catalyst surface including disappearance of active γ MnO2 phase in XRD, the reduction in average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn from 4.3 to 2.4 (calculated from energy separation of the splitting of Mn3s peakas, ΔEs as AOS=8.956-1.126 × ΔEs) and increase in porosity (specific surface area increased from 69 to 115 m2/g) (Figure 7(a-b), Table S1 and Figure S8, supporting information) [10]. In contrast, in the presence of NaHCO3 as additive, which suppressed Mn leaching, the catalyst could retain its structure, and chemical composition as characterised by retention of γ MnO2 peaks and the high avergage oxidation state (AOS) of Mn ∼4.3, which translated into improved reuse performance (Fig. 6-7 ). The compositional changes occurring in the Mn oxidation state during base free HMF oxidation is also supported by the characteristic broadening of Mn2p3/2 core peak, which was indicative of the formation of a dominant Mn2O3 phase via. reduction of MnO2, contributing to the reduced AOS of spent catalyst from base free reaction [51]. In contrast in the presence of NaHCO3, such drastic compositional changes in Mn oxidation state did not take (Figure S8, supporting information). Comparison of Ru3p core level of pristine and spent catalysts obtained from base free as well as NaHCO3 promoted reactions revealed that in all catalysts Ru remained in (IV) oxidation state which was in good agreement with the excellent hydrothermal stability of RuO2 phase [30,32,39,40]. Another, useful observation from XRD analysis of spent catalysts recovered from oxidation of 5 wt% and 10 wt% HMF substrates was the complete absence of characteristic peaks of MnO2 phase and the existence of well-defined peaks corresponding to Mn-FDCA, as opposed to the reactions performed with initial HMF concentration upto 2 wt%, where recovered catalysts retained features of active MnO2 phase (Figure S7(c), supporting information). Such observations were indicative of the promotional effects of increased FDCA concentration on undesired Mn-FDCA complex formation and its negative impact on catalyst reusability as well as desired product (FDCA) yield, and consistent with the observations made in Fig. 2(a). Overall, our experimental findings have important implications for the development of improved MnO2 based oxidation catalysts, and highlights the importance of acidic product (especially FDCA) induced Mn leaching to Mn-FDCA complexation in supported as well as unsupported MnO2 catalysts, Mn AOS and the role of weak bases such as NaHCO3 in preserving catalyst structure, and chemical composition during oxidative transformation of aqueous HMF to FDCA. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, base free HMF oxidation over RuMn-oxide based catalysts was revisited, which shows that the stability and performance of such catalysts are directly influence by process conditions. Our experiments identified acidic product (especially FDCA) induced MnO2 Mn leaching followed by its reaction FDCA leading to the formation of Mn-FDCA complex as the underlaying reason for loss of catalyst performance upon reuse. The formation of Mn-FDCA complex and Mn leaching was also confirmed from control experiments between FDCA and various Mn oxides under hydrothermal conditions. The structure of Mn-FDCA was confirmed by single crystal XRD. Among, various strategies explored (solubilization in organic solvents, in-situ ester and salt formation), oxidation in presence of stoichiometric amount of base (NaHCO3) was found to be most effective for inhibiting Mn leaching and Mn-FDCA complex formation. Moreover, use of base additive led to (i) improved carbon balance, (ii) increased oxidation rates, (iii) improved catalyst stability and (iv) simplified work up for product recovery. To summarize, our experimental findings have important implications for the development of improved Mn based oxidation catalysts for HMF transformation. coredata.dc:description: 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a high value bio-based chemical useful for the production of next generation renewable polymers, epoxy-resins and surfactants. Herein, we show that the performance and stability of MnO2 based oxidation catalysts used in FDCA production are considerably influence by process conditions (especially initial HMF conc. and presence of base additives). Although, base free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA is known to be highly effective over Ru modified MnO2 catalysts, our experiments showed considerable leaching of MnO2 phase under reaction conditions with the formation of insoluble Mn-FDCA complexes. The formation of Mn-FDCA complex and Mn leaching was also supported by control experiments between FDCA and various Mn oxides under hydrothermal conditions and its structure confirmed by single crystal XRD. Formation of Mn-FDCA and Mn leaching was also identified as the underlying reason for carbon balance deficit, catalyst mass loss and deactivation observed upon reuse.
coredata.dc:title: Base free HMF oxidation over Ru-MnO2 catalysts revisited: Evidence of Mn leaching to Mn-FDCA complexation and its implications on catalyst performance
